resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

issuetype.name: Task

fields.description:
Possibly related to: https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/ARROW/issues/ARROW-2770

Steps to reproduce:

{code}
$ conda create -n test python=3 pyarrow -c conda-forge -y
$ conda activate test
$ python -c 'import pyarrow'
{code}

This gives:

{code}
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/phillip/miniconda3/envs/py36/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pyarrow/__init__.py", line 47
, in <module>
    from pyarrow.lib import cpu_count, set_cpu_count
ImportError: libboost_system.so.1.65.1: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
{code}

Downgrading boost to {{1.65.1}} gives a symbol lookup error:

{code}
$ conda install boost-cpp=1.65.1 -y -c conda-forge
$ python -c 'import pyarrow'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/phillip/miniconda3/envs/py36/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pyarrow/__init__.py", line 47
, in <module>
    from pyarrow.lib import cpu_count, set_cpu_count
ImportError: /home/phillip/miniconda3/envs/py36/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pyarrow/../../../libarrow.so.0: undefined symbol: _ZN5boost13match_resultsIN9__gnu_cxx17__normal_iteratorIPKcNSt7__cxx1112basic_stringIcSt11char_traitsIcESaIcEEEEESaINS_9sub_matchISB_EEEE12maybe_assignERKSF_
{code}

Installing {{pyarrow}} from {{defaults}} and importing it works fine.

cc [~kszucs] [~xhochy]

comments.body:
On OSX with both python 2.7 and 3.6:

{code}
Python 3.6.5 | packaged by conda-forge | (default, Apr  6 2018, 13:44:09)
[GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Apple LLVM 6.1.0 (clang-602.0.53)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import pyarrow
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/krisz/.miniconda/envs/pina1/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pyarrow/__init__.py", line 47, in <module>
    from pyarrow.lib import cpu_count, set_cpu_count
ImportError: dlopen(/Users/krisz/.miniconda/envs/pina1/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pyarrow/lib.cpython-36m-darwin.so, 2): Symbol not found: __ZNK5boost16re_detail_10650131cpp_regex_traits_implementationIcE17transform_primaryEPKcS4_
  Referenced from: /Users/krisz/.miniconda/envs/pina1/lib/libparquet.1.dylib
  Expected in: /Users/krisz/.miniconda/envs/pina1/lib/libboost_regex.dylib
 in /Users/krisz/.miniconda/envs/pina1/lib/libparquet.1.dylib
{code}

Debian stretch produces similar undefined symbol error like Phillip has.

I'm confident this is related to the toolchain migration; [~xhochy] has been furiously moving things along but it has been rather chaotic. I haven't been able to spend much time maintaining the conda-forge PRs

Looks like {{parquet-cpp}} is somehow building against {{libboost=1.65.1}}: https://circleci.com/gh/conda-forge/parquet-cpp-feedstock/72?utm_campaign=vcs-integration-link&utm_medium=referral&utm_source=github-build-link

I'm not sure 1) how libboost is different from boost-cpp or 2) how it's possible to install different versions of these.
I've a bad feeling about [this pin|https://github.com/conda-forge/parquet-cpp-feedstock/blob/master/recipe/meta.yaml#L33]

Interestingly, this actually shows up as a build warning:

{code}
patchelf: file: /home/conda/feedstock_root/build_artifacts/parquet-cpp_1530403424640/_h_env_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold/lib/libparquet.so.1.4.0
    setting rpath to: $ORIGIN/.
WARNING (parquet-cpp,lib/libparquet.so.1.4.0): lib/libarrow.so.0 not found in any packages
WARNING (parquet-cpp,lib/libparquet.so.1.4.0): Needed DSO lib/libboost_regex.so.1.65.1 found in ['libboost']
WARNING (parquet-cpp,lib/libparquet.so.1.4.0): .. but ['libboost'] not in reqs/run, i.e. it is overlinked (likely) or a missing dependency (less likely)
WARNING (parquet-cpp,lib/libparquet.so.1.4.0): did not find - or even know where to look for: /lib64/libc.so.6
WARNING (parquet-cpp,lib/libparquet.so.1.4.0): lib/libstdc++.so.6 not found in any packages
WARNING (parquet-cpp,lib/libparquet.so.1.4.0): lib/libgcc_s.so.1 not found in any packages
WARNING (parquet-cpp,lib/libparquet.so.1.4.0): did not find - or even know where to look for: /lib64/libm.so.6
{code}

I'm going to look into trying to make the build fail on such warnings.

Should be fixed now again, will finish the migration with the {{pyarrow-feedstock}} now but the chain hopefully works again. Their automated bot changes sadly introduced some silent breakages due to the new way of pinning package versions and specifying windows support. Sadly as always with conda-forge, builds are stuck in a long queue in Travis.
[~kszucs] [~cpcloud] no need to investigate further between, I'm aware of the problems and also know the solutions. Simply the CI is blocking me.
[~xhochy] Would You please share the solution? :)
[~xhochy] Thanks for doing that. I too am curious to know what the solution is.

The solution is to rebuild the chain. The pinning changed to Boost 1.67 and the current release is build with 1.66 but through some magic I think it picks up an older version where we tried to vendor boost.
So we still depend on https://github.com/conda-forge/pyarrow-feedstock/pull/49
Vendoring is the wrong term: We had boost statically linked and the parquet-cpp was depening on some boost symbols that were statically linked into arrow-cpp.
Neither of arrow-cpp nor parquet-cpp are referencing pyarrow, and building parquet-cpp alone picks up the incorrect version of arrow and boost. Whatever, I'm curious about the outcome!

bq. Neither of arrow-cpp nor parquet-cpp are referencing pyarrow, and building parquet-cpp alone picks up the incorrect version of arrow and boost.

I thought that was fixed in the last 30-60min, can you retry? Only {{pyarrow}} should be broken now.

Ah, the conda-forge pinning also changed in the last 24h for boost. We also need to rebuild arrow-cpp. That is a mess as it will take hours.

[~wesmckinn] [~cpcloud] I'll try to fix things the next 2-3h but due to CI slowness, it would be nice if you could merge PRs when it's night in Europe. We currently have a parquet-cpp build with Boost 1.67 and no arrow-cpp build with Boost 1.66. I'm totally unsure why the CI in the PRs ever passed.
Will do.

I still think there's still an issue building {{parquet-cpp}} that depends on how conda is determining what version of {{arrow-cpp}} to install when building {{parquet-cpp}}. It installs an older version of {{arrow-cpp=0.9.0}} from defaults, which brings in {{libboost=1.65}} and causes {{parquet-cpp}} to build against that version of boost. When I build locally I can reproduce this problem. I'm going to keep digging.

It looks like I was wrong. Rebuilding {{arrow-cpp}} locally and using that as a channel to {{conda build}} allows {{parquet-cpp}} to pick up the latest {{arrow-cpp}} and build against the correct {{boost}} version. I'll submit a patch to the {{arrow-cpp}} conda-forge repo.
Looks like [~xhochy] beat me to it. :)

We need to rebuild {{arrow-cpp}} again. I think the following long chain of things will fix it:

1. Repin {{arrow-cpp}}: https://github.com/conda-forge/arrow-cpp-feedstock/pull/54
2. Merge above once CI passed
3. Wait for the {{arrow-cpp-feedstock}} CIs to upload the actual packages
4. Simply bump the build number of {{parquet-cpp}} to trigger a new build
5. Wait for CIs, merge wait for CIs
6. Retrigger/repin {{pyarrow-feedstock}}
Sounds good. [~xhochy] I will handle the rest.
Everything works again.

This problem isn't completely fixed.  There's still a conflict between pyarrow and libhdfs3 (which pyarrow uses), converging at boost-cpp.  I went to upgrade boost-cpp to fix this missing symbol problem, but found another conflict:
{code:java}
$ conda install 'boost-cpp>=1.67' -c conda-forge
Solving environment: failed

UnsatisfiableError: The following specifications were found to be in conflict:
- boost-cpp[version='>=1.67']
- libhdfs3=2.3-0 -> boost-cpp==1.66.0
Use "conda info <package>" to see the dependencies for each package.
{code}
Background:

My specific need was on feather (which pulls in pyarrow and causes the conflict) and hdfs3.  Not to hijack this thread, but if there's another way around that specific problem, then I'm not stalled out any more.
Sorry, reading this whole thread. Let's migrate the discussion to conda-forge: https://github.com/conda-forge/arrow-cpp-feedstock/issues/59
